title: UF Environmental Health and Safety
cleaned_text: Wildlife Field Research [Research Safety & Personnel](https://www.ehs.ufl.edu/departments/research-safety-services/biosafety/vaccination-for-research-personnel/) - [Chemical and the or Completion](https://www.ehs.ufl.edu/departments/facility-support-services/building-codes-enforcement/certificate-of-occupancy-%e2%80%a8or-completion/) [Applicable Building Codes for the State of Florida and the University of Florida](https://www.ehs.ufl.edu/departments/facility-support-services/building-codes-enforcement/codes-and-standards/) [Code Permits](https://www.ehs.ufl.edu/departments/facility-support-services/building-codes-enforcement/chartfield-form-codes-permits/) - [Fire Plan Review and Inspection](https://www.ehs.ufl.edu/departments/facility-support-services/fire-safety/) [Pest Management](https://www.ehs.ufl.edu/departments/facility-support-services/pest-management/) A Wildlife Field Safety Plan must be in place before work starts. [A Wildlife Field Research Safety Plan template](/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Wildlife_Research_Safety_Plan.docx) is available for use. The IACUC protocol, Section 22.2.5, must outline potential zoonotic diseases, physical hazards, and allergens and precautions necessary for staff to minimize the risks. - Describe the relevant safety and containment procedures that will be used to mitigate project risks and protect personnel. Consider the effect of non-target animals, the necessary safety equipment, work practices, and PPE that will be required for various tasks (e.g. capturing animals, animal inoculation). - Discuss the specific hazards/risks that you may encounter in the field associated with this experiment (e.g. potential exposure risks such as needlesticks, animal/insect bites, parasites, exotic/poisonous plants, or venomous animals).
